PR 370Collection processed by Zora ArumNew-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024Phone: (212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-09-19T17:17:27EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
New-York Historical Society
Gramercy Neighborhood Associates collection
Gramercy Neighborhood Associates
PR 370
.63 Linear Feet in two document boxes.
circa 1892-2002 (bulk undated) The collection primarily consists of photographs of Gramercy Park and the surrounding area, including street, park, building exteriors, and aerial views. There are also eight fiction and non-fiction books about Gramercy Park and related historical figures.
Arrangement
The collection is arranged in two document boxes. Box 1, a half document box, contains nine folders of photographs, relocated from an original three binders, and Box 2 contains books.
Most of the photographs are reproductions of originals and the bulk are undated. The date ranges shown in the container list are approximations of the date of the original image, not necessarily the date of the collection's copy.
Biographical / Historical
Gramercy Neighborhood Associates is a nonprofit organization made up primarily of Gramercy Park residents. The organization was founded in 1912, in part united by a collective effort to prevent the passage of a bill that would have bisected Gramercy Park in order to connect Lexington Avenue and Irving Place. Since then, Gramercy Neighborhood Associates has engaged in a variety of community service projects, including hosting events for residents such as the Annual Art Show, sponsoring neighborhood renovations such as replacing modern lampposts with Bishop Crook Lampposts in order to reestablish Gramercy's historic aesthetic, and engaging with schools and local businesses in the Gramercy Park area.
Access Restrictions
Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.
Use Restrictions
Permission to reproduce any Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, September 2017.
Preferred Citation
The collection should be cited as the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates collection, PR 370, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit Line: Gift of the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, 2017.
Scope and Contents
The collection is comprised of approximately 150 photographs and eight fiction and non-fiction books about Gramercy Park and related historical figures.
The photographs are of Gramercy Park and its surrounding areas, including Union Square Park, Madison Square Park, Stuyvesant Town, and Peter Cooper Village. Most of the photographs are reproductions of images from the mid 1800s through the twentieth century, though there are many original documents found throughout. The earliest original photograph appears to date from about 1892. The photographs are mainly views of streets, parks and building exteriors, along with a number of aerial shots. Images of buildings include a few under construction, such as the Flatiron Building (1902) and the Metropolitan Life Insurance building (1907-08). All of the photos are black-and-white, except for a set from 1989 taken by Consolidated Edison. The container list provides further detail, and Folder 1 contains a detailed inventory provided by the donor of the photographs' subjects.
The books in the collection are listed individually in the container list.
All materials in the collection appear to have been compiled by the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates, but do not pertain to the organization itself.
Processing Information
The collection was processed by archival intern Zora Arum in 2018.

Scope and Contents
Folder includes, among other images, the parade for the cornerstone ceremony of Washington Irving School, construction of Flatiron and Metropolitan Life Insurance buildings, Episcopal Church Mission House, Fourth Ave street scene (1926), Stuyvesant Fish House/Sonnenberg Mansion, Clarendon Hotel.Photographs (folder 2 of 9)circa 1880s-194612
Scope and Contents
Includes, among other images, Irving Place, New Amsterdam Hotel, trolley cars and horsecars, Union Square, aerial of Madison Square Park/Metropolitan Life building area, aerial of construction site of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village (1946), and bar at Scheffel Hall.Photographs (folder 3 of 9)circa 1870-1960s?13
Scope and Contents
Includes, among other images, interior of Scheffel Hall, Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church, All Souls Unitarian Church, Everett House, original Metropolitan Life building at Park and 23rd (as seen in 1950s?), Gramercy Park, and street views.Photographs (folder 4 of 9)circa 1853-1950s?14
Scope and Contents
Includes, among other images, Gramercy Park and rowhouses surrounding the park and Stanford White house (original photos by Ameniya).Photographs (folder 5 of 9)circa 1898-1950s?15
Scope and Contents
Includes, among other images, Japanese bronze lantern from Stanford White residence, Peter Cooper and Abram S. Hewitt home after 1883 stoop alteration, and Gramercy Park statuary and scenes (including winter).Photographs (folder 6 of 9)circa 1892-195916
Scope and Contents
Includes, among other images, Christmas tree in Gramercy Park, Stanford White house, Irving Place, original photo of horsecars at Union Square in winter (1892), National Academy of Design & Lyceum Theatre (1894), aerial view of Gramercy Park, and Free Academy of New York.Photographs (folder 7-8 of 9)198917-8
Scope and Contents
Color photos taken by Consolidated Edison: aerial views of 3rd Avenue and 20th Street area, and ground level views of Gramercy Park area work sites, including buildings wrapped in white sheathing.Photographs (folder 9 of 9)circa 1900-1950s?19
Scope and Contents
